info.game_comments:
Tom Morris game 4.
Returning untied co-champions.
Only one contestant interview.
One clue recycled from #3811, aired 2001-03-12 and three clues recycled from #3913, aired 2001-09-12.

(1, 1).clue: Members of the House of Representatives serve terms of this many years

(2, 1).clue: On a "Manic Monday", this group taught us to "Walk Like an Egyptian"

(3, 1).clue: This Las Vegas hotel & casino has 3 thrill rides on its 1,149-foot tower

(4, 1).clue: Born in Germany in 1879, he fled to America in 1932 & became a U.S. citizen in 1940

(5, 1).clue: In 1901 he joined with a machinist named Nickerson to make his safety razor

(6, 1).clue: It's a whaler's weapon of choice

(1, 2).clue: He appointed more justices (9) to the Supreme Court than any other president in the 20th century

(2, 2).clue: This group was "Headin' down the Atlanta Highway... headin' on down to the Love Shack"

(3, 2).clue: The lateral halves of the cerebrum are called these

(4, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reports from the NASA White Sands Test Facility in New Mexico.)  To develop U.S. rockets like the Redstone, many German scientists were brought to America after World War II, including this chief designer of the Saturn V

(5, 2).clue: Based in Laufen, Switzerland, this company makes cough drops & breath mints from alpine herbs

(6, 2).clue: Mary Poppins told us that this "of sugar helps the medicine go down in a most delightful way"

(1, 3).clue: You'll find its home page at www.uscg.mil

(2, 3).clue: On the Michael Jackson hit "Beat It", this virtuoso lead guitarist played a solo

(3, 3).clue: You can take a tour under the glass of this Arizona facility seen here

(4, 3).clue: He published his quantum theory in 1900 while a professor of physics in Berlin

(5, 3).clue: In 1903 James L. Kraft began a company to handle the wholesale distribution of this food

(6, 3).clue: A type of camera lens, or to go really fast

(1, 4).clue: This document served as our basic charter of government from 1781 until the Constitution in 1789

(2, 4).clue: This 1983 Police album gave the world "Every Breath You Take" & "Wrapped Around Your Finger"

(3, 4).clue: The name of this layer of the Sun comes partly from the Greek for "light"

(4, 4).clue: He became president of the Royal Society in 1703 & was reelected annually until his death in 1727

(5, 4).clue: In 1959 the Ohio Art toy company got the rights to l'Ecran magique, the Magic Writer, & renamed it this

(6, 4).clue: A portable music player with large speakers

(1, 5).clue: It's the F in the outdoors-oriented agency known as FWS

(2, 5).clue: This band's first album, which included "Blister In The Sun", went platinum without making the Top 40

(3, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the National Geographic Society's Explorers Hall.) The National Geographic Society has a replica of this device that William Beebe invented & in which he descended to a record 3,028 feet off Bermuda in 1934

(4, 5).clue: His uncertainty principle says a particle's position & momentum can't be known simultaneously

(5, 5).clue: The name of this fruit & vegetable canner came from a hotel in Monterey

(6, 5).clue: A light, good-hearted satire, or a "National" magazine that does satire

(1, 1).clue: 1 of the 2 Australian states with "Australia" in their names

(2, 1).clue: This A.A. Milne feline finally earned his stripes: he got his own movie in 2000

(3, 1).clue: If Anouilh gives you ennui, you may not want to see "The Lark", his play about this female saint

(4, 1).clue: The 1946 film "Night and Day" was about this composer who wrote "Begin the Beguine" & "It's De-Lovely"

(5, 1).clue: In 1610 he described the moon as seen in his telescope as having a "rough and unequal" surface

(6, 1).clue: Lettuce tell you the term "salad" comes from the French salade, meaning with this seasoning

(1, 2).clue: There are first-person accounts of this volcano's eruption in 1767 (as there had been in 79 A.D.)

(2, 2).clue: Someone left the cat out in the rain in this 1961 film (P.S.--it was Audrey Hepburn)

(3, 2).clue: Founded in the 1600s, the Comedie Francaise is also known as "La maison de" this comic playwright

(4, 2).clue: This physician ran for president as a Libertarian in 1988 & as a Republican in 2008

(5, 2).clue: Last name of Nathaniel, who fostered a 1676 rebellion against Virginia governor Berkeley's Indian policies

(6, 2).clue: From the Dutch for "a twisted cake", it's a twisted doughnut

(1, 3).clue: Staffordshire's chief river is the Trent, & its largest city is this-"on-Trent"

(2, 3).clue: Fans of a 1940 Disney film know that Figaro the cat belongs to this woodcarver

(3, 3).clue: Andre de Lorde was the master of the gruesome French thrillers in this "Grand" gory genre

(5, 3).clue: In 1632 this Lord was granted a charter to found the colony of Maryland

(6, 3).clue: Derived from the Latin word for "body", it's used to describe a large or bulky person

(1, 4).clue: On 11/27/00 King Harald V opened this country's Laerdal Highway Tunnel, the world's longest at 15.2 miles

(2, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Sean Hayes.)  I could tell you a Thing One or a Thing Two about this film: I played Mr. Humberfloob & the voice of the fish in it

(3, 4).clue: "La Revolution Francaise" was the 1st musical collaboration by Boublil & Schonberg; this mega-hit was 2nd

(4, 4).clue: On May 7, 1960 Soviet leader Khrushchev announced his nation was holding this American as a spy

(5, 4).clue: In the 1697 Treaty of Rijswijk, the French recognized this Dutch-born man as King of England

(6, 4).clue: From the Greek for "generalship", it's a plan of action, like those employed by the military

(1, 5).clue: These 2 republics united in 1964 to form Tanzania

(2, 5).clue: This villain's face was never shown in his first film, "From Russia with Love", but we did get a good look at his cat

(3, 5).clue: The French play "The Madwoman of" this place inspired Jerry Herman's Broadway musical "Dear World"

(4, 5).clue: Born around 1550, this man also known as Wahunsonacock came to wield enormous power in what is now Va.

(5, 5).clue: Born aboard the Mayflower in the New World, he grew up to be a captain of militia--maybe a falconer too

(6, 5).clue: From the Old French for "man", it's a special honor expressed publicly for a person

(0, 0).clue: Circled 7 times by the Israelites in Joshua, it's said to be the world's oldest walled city
